fields.value: Employers and Older Workers: CRR Survey Data. 2006

authorName.value: Boston College. Center for Retirement Research

authorAffiliation.value: Boston College. Center for Retirement Research

datasetContactName.value: Boston College. Center for Retirement Research

datasetContactAffiliation.value: Boston College. Center for Retirement Research

dsDescriptionValue.value: To get a better understanding of the employment prospects of older workers, the Center for Retirement Research has conducted two surveys of 400 private-sector for-profit and non-profit employers. The surveys were conducted by telephone by Matthew Greenwald & Associates. Below, you may access the questionnaire, results, and raw data from both surveys.

publicationCitation.value: Munnell, Alicia Haydock, Mauricio Soto, and Steven A. Sass. Employer attitudes toward older workers: Survey results. Work Opportunities for Older Americans 3, Chestnut Hill, Mass.: Center for Retirement Research at Boston College, July 2006. http://hdl.handle.net/2345/bc-ir:104455 Note: Version of record.

fields.value:
EMPLOYER VIEWS ON WORKER RETIREMENT PREPAREDNESS AND WORK EXPECTATIONS
In the second CRR survey, employers were asked to estimate how many workers currently in their 50s will have the resources needed to retire at the organization’s traditional age and how many unprepared workers will respond by opting to extend their careers. (files: qr_2.doc and codebook2.xls)
EMPLOYER ATTITUDES TOWARDS OLDER WORKERS
In the first CRR survey, employers were asked the relative productivity and cost of white-collar and rank-and-file workers age 55 and older and whether, on balance, older employees or job candidates were more or less attractive than their younger counterparts. (files: q_r.doc and codebook.xls)
Contact for assistance: datasupport@bc.edu
